action.action-desc: Ms. DeLauro (for herself, Ms. Lee of California, Mr. DeFazio, Mr. Clay, and Mr. Grijalva) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to deny any deduction for marketing directed at children to promote the consumption of food of poor nutritional quality.

section.header: Denial of deduction for marketing directed at children to promote food of poor nutritional quality

subsection.text: Part IX of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to items not deductible) is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

section.header: Denial of deduction for marketing directed at children to promote food of poor nutritional quality

subsection.text: No deduction shall be allowed under this chapter with respect to—

paragraph.text: any marketing directed at children for purposes of promoting the consumption by children of food of poor nutritional quality, and
any of the following which are incurred or provided primarily for purposes described in paragraph (1):

subparagraph.text: Goods or services of a type generally considered to constitute entertainment, amusement, or recreation or the use of a facility in connection with providing such goods and services.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the term food of poor nutritional quality means food and beverages that are determined by the Secretary (in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Federal Trade Commission) to be inconsistent with the most recent Dietary Guidelines for Americans published under section 301 of the National Nutrition Monitoring and Related Research Act of 1990 (7 U.S.C. 5341).
For purposes of this section, the term marketing means all product and brand advertising and promotional techniques directed at children, including—

paragraph.text: advertising (including product placement) on television and radio, in print media, in social media, and on the Internet (including third-party and company-sponsored websites),
advertising preceding a movie shown in a movie theater or placed on a video (DVD or VHS) or within a video game or mobile application,
promotional content transmitted to personal computers and other digital or mobile devices,
advertising displays and promotions at the retail site,
specialty or premium items distributed in connection with the sale of a product or a product loyalty program,
promotion character licensing, toy co-branding and cross-promotions,

subsection.continuation-text: For purposes of the preceding sentence, the term directed at includes the use of measured media if the audience for such media will consist of 35 percent or more of children.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the term child means an individual who is age 17 or under.

The Secretary shall (in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Federal Trade Commission) prescribe such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this section.
The table of sections for such part IX is amended by adding at the end the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 280I. Denial of deduction for marketing directed at children to promote food of poor nutritional quality.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to amounts paid or incurred after the date of the enactment of this Act in taxable years ending after such date.
